statement (text): You can't get an STI the first time you have sex.
explanation: You can get an STI any time you have sex with someone who has an STI.

statement (text): You can't get an STI from oral sex.
explanation: Oral sex can transmit several STIs (e.g., herpes, chlamydia, gonorrhea, syphilis, HPV). Use condoms/dental dams.

statement (text): Using a male condom and a female condom together gives you double protection.
explanation: Don't use male and female condoms together—friction increases the chance of breakage.

statement (text): Douching can help protect you from HIV.
explanation: Douching can actually increase HIV risk by disrupting protective vaginal flora.

statement (text): You'll know if you have an STI because you'll have symptoms.
explanation: Many STIs have no symptoms. Testing is needed to know for sure.

statement (text): Only teenagers get STIs.
explanation: STIs can affect people of any age; diagnoses have risen among older adults too.

statement (text): You can get an STI if you have multiple partners.
explanation: Having multiple partners increases your risk of STIs (though even one encounter can transmit).

statement (text): If I'm pregnant with an STI, it won't affect my fetus.
explanation: Some STIs can be passed to the baby during pregnancy, delivery, or breastfeeding; early treatment helps prevent this.

statement (text): Men and women have the same symptoms for STIs.
explanation: Symptoms vary by infection and person; some infections are asymptomatic or present differently in different people.

statement (text): All STIs can be cured.
explanation: Symptoms vary by infection and person; some infections are asymptomatic or present differently in different people.

statement (text): STIs do not cause infertility.
explanation: Untreated STIs like chlamydia can cause PID and infertility.

statement (text): Cold sores are an STI.
explanation: Cold sores are usually HSV‑1 and often acquired non‑sexually in childhood, but they can be sexually transmitted via oral sex.

statement (text): You can get an STI from a toilet seat.
explanation: STIs are not transmitted via toilet seats, food, utensils, or handshakes.

statement (text): Oral sex is safe sex.
explanation: Oral sex still carries STI risk; use condoms/dental dams.

statement (text): You can always tell if someone has an STI.
explanation: You can't tell by looking—many STIs have no visible signs.

statement (text): Only gay men get HIV.
explanation: HIV can affect anyone regardless of sexual orientation; risk depends on behaviors, not identity.

statement (text): Pulling out before ejaculation is safe against STIs.
explanation: Withdrawal doesn't protect against STIs; pre‑ejaculate and skin‑to‑skin contact can transmit infections.

statement (text): HIV can be transmitted through any bodily fluid.
explanation: HIV is transmitted by specific fluids (blood, semen, rectal/vaginal fluids, breast milk)—not by sweat, saliva, or urine in everyday contact.

statement (text): Condoms are highly effective at preventing most STIs when used correctly.
explanation: Correct and consistent condom use is highly effective for many STIs, though not 100% and less so for skin‑to‑skin infections.

statement (text): Regular STI testing is important for sexually active individuals.
explanation: Regular testing (e.g., every 6–12 months, or with new partners) helps detect asymptomatic infections.

statement (text): Some STIs can be transmitted through skin-to-skin contact.
explanation: STIs like herpes and HPV can spread via intimate skin‑to‑skin contact.

statement (text): STIs are more common in certain age groups.
explanation: Teens and young adults have higher rates in many places.

statement (text): Having an STI increases your risk of contracting HIV.
explanation: STIs can increase the risk of getting or transmitting HIV; testing and treatment reduce risk.

statement (text): Pregnant women should be tested for STIs.
explanation: Testing and treating STIs in pregnancy helps protect the baby from infection.

statement (text): Some STIs can cause cancer.
explanation: HPV can lead to cervical, anal, and some head & neck cancers.

statement (text): Vaccines are available for some STIs.
explanation: Vaccines exist for hepatitis B and HPV.

statement (text): You can get reinfected with the same STI after treatment.
explanation: You can get the same STI again after treatment if re‑exposed.

statement (text): STIs only affect your reproductive organs.
explanation: STIs can affect the mouth, throat, rectum, skin, and other body systems.

statement (text): Birth control pills protect against STIs.
explanation: Hormonal contraception does not protect against STIs; condoms are needed for STI prevention.

statement (text): You can cure HIV with natural remedies.
explanation: There is no cure for HIV; effective treatment suppresses the virus but does not eradicate it.

statement (text): You don’t need to test as long as you have not had many sex partners
explanation: Even one sexual encounter can transmit an STI; number of partners only affects risk level.

statement (text): I don’t need to thinkabout sexually transmitted infections as they can be treated  and cured easily
explanation: Some STIs can be managed or cured, but others (e.g., HIV, herpes) are lifelong; drug‑resistant strains also exist.

statement (text): You will only get the same sexually transmitted infection once
explanation: You can be reinfected with the same STI multiple times if re‑exposed.

statement (text): My partner and I are monogamous, so there is no need to get tested.
explanation: Even in new monogamous relationships, past infections can be present; partners should test at the start of the relationship.

statement (text): Syphilis is a historical disease that no one gets anymore.
explanation: Syphilis remains present and diagnoses have increased in recent years.

statement (text): STI testing is quite painful.
explanation: Most STI tests involve urine or blood tests; swabs may be used for symptoms and are typically only mildly uncomfortable.

statement (text): It’s embarrassing to get tested for STIs.
explanation: There’s no shame in caring for your health; clinicians handle STI testing routinely and confidentially.

statement (text): Using two condoms at once (double-bagging) gives extra protection.
explanation: Layering condoms increases friction and the chance of breakage—use one condom correctly with water-based lubricant.

statement (text): STI testing always involves a physical exam of your genitals.
explanation: If you have no symptoms, many tests are urine, blood, or self-collected swabs; exams are needed mainly when symptoms are present.

statement (text): Hot‑tub sex minimizes your risk of STIs.
explanation: Chlorine or hot-tub water does not prevent STIs and may increase risk of other infections.

statement (text): You won’t get an STI if you don’t have sex.
explanation: Some STIs can spread without intercourse, including via needles, blood contact, or from parent to baby; certain infections can spread by intimate skin or oral contact.

statement (text): Your partner doesn’t need STI testing unless you have an infection.
explanation: Both partners should test; one person can be infected without symptoms and transmit to the other.

statement (text): STIs don’t require medical intervention.
explanation: Many STIs need diagnosis and treatment to prevent complications; some are chronic and require ongoing care.

statement (text): Active adults are more likely to get STIs than teens.
explanation: Teens and young adults often have higher STI rates due to factors like unprotected sex and limited access to care.

statement (text): Condoms protect against all STIs.
explanation: Condoms are highly effective for many STIs but are not 100% and offer less protection for skin‑to‑skin infections (e.g., HPV, herpes).

statement (text): You can always tell if you have Chlamydia.
explanation: Many people with Chlamydia have no symptoms at all.

statement (text): Chlamydia always causes pain or visible sores.
explanation: Some cases of Chlamydia are asymptomatic or show very mild signs.

statement (text): If you don't feel sick, you don't have Chlamydia.
explanation: Chlamydia can be present even without noticeable symptoms.

statement (text): Only women show symptoms of Chlamydia.
explanation: Both men and women can have Chlamydia, with or without symptoms.

statement (text): Chlamydia symptoms go away on their own, so it's nothing to worry about.
explanation: Even if symptoms fade, Chlamydia can remain and cause complications without treatment.

statement (text): Chlamydia doesn't cause any long-term health problems.
explanation: Chlamydia can cause long-term complications like infertility or organ damage if untreated.

statement (text): Only serious infections like HIV can affect fertility, not Chlamydia.
explanation: Many STIs including Chlamydia can affect fertility in both men and women.

statement (text): Chlamydia will go away on its own without causing harm.
explanation: Without treatment, Chlamydia can persist and cause serious health issues.

statement (text): Chlamydia only affects the private parts.
explanation: Chlamydia can affect other parts of the body, not just genitals.

statement (text): Health problems from Chlamydia only happen in women.
explanation: Chlamydia can cause serious issues in both men and women.

statement (text): You can only get Chlamydia through vaginal sex.
explanation: Chlamydia can spread through vaginal, oral, or anal sex.

statement (text): You can't get Chlamydia from oral or anal sex.
explanation: Chlamydia can transmit through various types of sexual contact.

statement (text): Chlamydia can be spread through toilet seats.
explanation: Chlamydia is not spread through toilet seats or casual contact.

statement (text): Using a condom once prevents Chlamydia forever.
explanation: Condoms reduce risk but don't offer 100% protection every time.

statement (text): You can't get Chlamydia if your partner looks healthy.
explanation: People can transmit Chlamydia even without visible symptoms.

statement (text): Washing after sex can prevent Chlamydia.
explanation: Hygiene does not prevent Chlamydia; protection and testing are key.

statement (text): Birth control pills protect against Chlamydia.
explanation: Birth control prevents pregnancy, not STIs like Chlamydia.

statement (text): Having one loyal partner guarantees you won't get Chlamydia.
explanation: Even with one partner, STI risk exists if one person is infected.

statement (text): You don't need regular STI tests if you feel fine.
explanation: Regular testing helps detect Chlamydia early, even without symptoms.

statement (text): Only people with multiple partners need to worry about Chlamydia.
explanation: Anyone who is sexually active can get Chlamydia, not just those with many partners.

statement (text): Antibiotics can cure all STIs including Chlamydia.
explanation: Some STIs like Chlamydia are viral and cannot be cured with antibiotics.

statement (text): Once you take medicine for Chlamydia, you can't get it again.
explanation: You can get reinfected with Chlamydia even after treatment.

statement (text): You can treat Chlamydia with home remedies or herbs.
explanation: Chlamydia requires medical diagnosis and proper treatment, not home remedies.

statement (text): If symptoms disappear, Chlamydia is completely cured.
explanation: Symptoms may go away, but Chlamydia might still be in your body.

statement (text): There's no need to tell your partner if you have Chlamydia.
explanation: It's important to inform partners so they can get tested and treated too.

explanation: Birth control prevents pregnancy, not STIs like Syphilis.

statement (text): Having one loyal partner guarantees you won't get Syphilis.
explanation: Even with one partner, STI risk exists if one person is infected.

statement (text): You don't need regular STI tests if you feel fine.
explanation: Regular testing helps detect Syphilis early, even without symptoms.

statement (text): Only people with multiple partners need to worry about Syphilis.
explanation: Anyone who is sexually active can get Syphilis, not just those with many partners.

statement (text): Antibiotics can cure all STIs including Syphilis.
explanation: Some STIs like Syphilis are viral and cannot be cured with antibiotics.

statement (text): Once you take medicine for Syphilis, you can't get it again.
explanation: You can get reinfected with Syphilis even after treatment.

statement (text): You can treat Syphilis with home remedies or herbs.
explanation: Syphilis requires medical diagnosis and proper treatment, not home remedies.

statement (text): If symptoms disappear, Syphilis is completely cured.
explanation: Symptoms may go away, but Syphilis might still be in your body.

statement (text): There's no need to tell your partner if you have Syphilis.
explanation: It's important to inform partners so they can get tested and treated too.

statement (text): You can always tell if you have Chancroid.
explanation: Many people with Chancroid have no symptoms at all.

statement (text): Chancroid always causes pain or visible sores.
explanation: Some cases of Chancroid are asymptomatic or show very mild signs.

statement (text): If you don't feel sick, you don't have Chancroid.
explanation: Chancroid can be present even without noticeable symptoms.

statement (text): Only women show symptoms of Chancroid.
explanation: Both men and women can have Chancroid, with or without symptoms.

statement (text): Chancroid symptoms go away on their own, so it's nothing to worry about.
explanation: Even if symptoms fade, Chancroid can remain and cause complications without treatment.

statement (text): Chancroid doesn't cause any long-term health problems.
explanation: Chancroid can cause long-term complications like infertility or organ damage if untreated.

statement (text): Only serious infections like HIV can affect fertility, not Chancroid.
explanation: Many STIs including Chancroid can affect fertility in both men and women.

statement (text): Chancroid will go away on its own without causing harm.
explanation: Without treatment, Chancroid can persist and cause serious health issues.

statement (text): Chancroid only affects the private parts.
explanation: Chancroid can affect other parts of the body, not just genitals.

statement (text): Health problems from Chancroid only happen in women.
explanation: Chancroid can cause serious issues in both men and women.

statement (text): You can only get Chancroid through vaginal sex.
explanation: Chancroid can spread through vaginal, oral, or anal sex.

statement (text): You can't get Chancroid from oral or anal sex.
explanation: Chancroid can transmit through various types of sexual contact.

statement (text): Chancroid can be spread through toilet seats.
explanation: Chancroid is not spread through toilet seats or casual contact.

statement (text): Using a condom once prevents Chancroid forever.
explanation: Condoms reduce risk but don't offer 100% protection every time.

statement (text): You can't get Chancroid if your partner looks healthy.
explanation: People can transmit Chancroid even without visible symptoms.
